rename.from: Support for Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Object Storage
rename.to: Support for Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Object Storage  as native backend.

rename.from: Support for Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Object Storage  as native backend.
rename.to: Support for oracle cloud infrastructure (oci) object storage  as native backend.

body:
Is there a Go library to access OCI?

Writing and maintaining a backend is a lot of work! Is there any way we could extend the s3 backend to read some auth from the native api, but use the S3 api for access?

**Q) Is there a Go library to access OCI?** 
yes there is oci-go-sdk which has all the clients to access OCI. For object storage its here https://github.com/oracle/oci-go-sdk/tree/master/objectstorage

**Q) Writing and maintaining a backend is a lot of work! Is there any way we could extend the s3 backend to read some auth from the native api, but use the S3 api for access?**

Yes, agreed, it's a lot of work.

The [S3 Compat mode](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Object/Tasks/s3compatibleapi.htm) api only accepts AWS4-HMAC-SHA256 Authorization headers unfortunately. Trying to pass native Auth headers result in throwing exception that it only accepts amzn auth headers. 

So I tried to use Instance Principal security token into AWS4-HMAC-SHA256 Auth Header, which resulted in Mismatch Signature. Talking to internal teams, it appears that, it is not supported to associate S3 compatible credentials for resource principals, instance principals. Let me investigate on this more.

@ncw synced with our internal team members, the s3 compat endpoint doesn't support Instance Principals and work to support both auth ([aws4](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/API/sigv4-auth-using-authorization-header.html), [oci signature v1](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/signingrequests.htm)) via s3 compat endpoint is probably not going to happen. 

 So option is to add it as a new backend integrating with oci-go-sdk with [oci signature v1](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/API/Concepts/signingrequests.htm)
work in progress in my private remote, will post here once its ready.

issue.title: oracle-object-storage: Add a new native backend -fixes #6299

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
<!--
Thank you very much for contributing code or documentation to rclone! Please
fill out the following questions to make it easier for us to review your
changes.

You do not need to check all the boxes below all at once, feel free to take
your time and add more commits. If you're done and ready for review, please
check the last box.
-->

#### What is the purpose of this change?
Add support for new native backend: Oracle Object Storage
Existing access via s3 compat way works but it works with only access-key, secret-key which forces users to pass credentials around
Native way works with OCI config file, Instance Principal, Resource Principal way and hits the native end points. 
Instance Principal way is great for automation, in the sense that customer's do not have to mess with secrets on oci compute instance for bucket access 
<!--

-->

#### Was the change discussed in an issue or in the forum before?
https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/6299
<!--
[Link issues and relevant forum posts here.]
-->

#### Checklist

- [X] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#submitting-a-new-feature-or-bug-fix).
- [X]  I have added tests for all changes in this PR if appropriate.
- [X] I have added documentation for the changes if appropriate.
- [x] All commit messages are in [house style](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit-messages).
- [x] I'm done, this Pull Request is ready for review :-)

body: @ncw please take a look at the PR when you get some free time. thank you. It needs a maintainer's approval to do run the workflow.

> @msays2000 Ok that sounds like a reasonable argument. You have my blessing to make a new backend for this :-)
> 
> Follow the script here: https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#writing-a-new-backend
> 
> Note that s3 isn't a good backend to start from as it is very complicated though I would refer to the code. I'd probably start from one of the simpler bucket based backends like `b2` or `azureblob`.

@ncw https://github.com/rclone/rclone/pull/6332 done..
@ncw or anyone else maintainer of this project, please review the PR
